The Fetch API

... About 4 min

# The Fetch API

# A modern replacement forÂ XMLHttpRequest

It is said thatÂ "Necessity is the mother of all inventions"Â and that's what fueled the development of Fetch API. But before digging deeper into the Fetch API let's dive into the history behind it.

# AJAX

BeforeÂ AJAXÂ (Asynchronous JavaScript and XML) concept was introduced, to update the portion of a page, browsers at that time used to make a request for a full web page to the server, after the request was received by the server, it used to create and return a page to the browser as a response.Â It means that even for a small change the page was loaded entirely. That was bad right? Very very bad.

AfterÂ AJAXÂ came into the world of internet, it changed the traditional way of updating the page. WithÂ AJAX, Web applications were able to send and retrieve data from a serverÂ asynchronouslyÂ (in the background) without interfering with the display and behaviour of the existing page.

# XMLHttpRequest

In 2006 theÂ World Wide Web ConsortiumÂ published a working draft specification for theÂ XMLHttpRequestÂ object.Â XMLHttpRequestÂ object is used to retrieve data from a server asynchronously. In the initial stages,Â XMLHttpRequestÂ used to fetchÂ XMLÂ data overÂ HTTPÂ hence the name. But today it can be used with protocols other thanÂ HTTPÂ and it can fetch data not only in the form ofÂ XMLÂ but alsoÂ JSON,Â HTMLÂ orÂ plain text.

The original concept behind theÂ XMLHttpRequestÂ object was originally created by the developers of Outlook Web Access (by Microsoft).

So let's try with an example, we will make a simple request usingÂ XMLHttpRequest, get a response and parse it asÂ JSON.

var xhr = new XMLHttpRequest();
xhr.onload = function() {
    var data = JSON.parse(this.responseText);
    console.log(data);
};
xhr.onerror = function(err) {
    console.log('Error Occurred :', err);
};
xhr.open('GET', 'https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/todos');
xhr.send();

We needÂ twoÂ listeners to be set to handle the success and error cases and then a call toÂ open() the request, providing the request type and url, thanÂ send() to fire the request. The response from the server is stored in theÂ responseTextÂ variable, which is converted toÂ JavaScript objectÂ usingÂ JSON.parse().

We have usedÂ XMLHttpRequestÂ for several years to request data other thanÂ XML, and that's where the confusion starts when a beginner trys to learn how to make an asynchronous request in JavaScript.

Isn't there a cleaner and simple API to make an asynchronous request?

Well yes, there is and for that, we fast forward to today.

# Fetch

Fetch is a native JavaScript API, supported by most browsers today.Â Fetch allows you to make network requests similar toÂ XMLHttpRequest. According toÂ Google Developers Documentation (opens new window)Â Fetch makes it easier to make asynchronous requests and handle responses better than with the olderÂ XMLHttpRequest.Â It is an improvement over theÂ XMLHttpRequestÂ API in both complexity and functionality.Â The main difference between Fetch andÂ XMLHttpRequestÂ is that the Fetch API uses Promises, hence avoiding callback hell.

If you are new toÂ promisesÂ then check outÂ JavaScript Promises: an Introduction (opens new window).

# Fetch Interfaces

The Fetch API has following interfaces

  • fetch() (opens new window): TheÂ fetch()Â method used to fetch a resource.
  • Headers (opens new window): Represents response/request headers, allowing you to query them and take different actions depending on the results.
  • Request (opens new window): Represents a resource request.
  • Response (opens new window): Represents the response to a request.

# Making a request using fetch()

AÂ fetch() (opens new window)Â function is available in the globalÂ windowÂ object.Â TheÂ fetch()Â function takes one mandatory argument, the path to the resource you want to fetch.Â It returns aÂ Promise, whether it is successful or not. If request is successfulÂ .then()Â function will receiveÂ ResponseÂ object, if request fails thenÂ .catch()Â function will receive anÂ errorÂ object

fetch('https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/todos')
    .then(function (response) {
        console.log(response);
    })
    .catch(function (err) {
        console.log("Something went wrong!", err);
    });

# The Response Object

The above code makes use of Fetch API and makes a call to GitHub to fetch data about the user.Â When the promise is resolved we get aÂ ResponseÂ object in return. But wait, if you try loggingÂ ResponseÂ object on the console you will find that it didn't have the data which we want. That's because aÂ ResponseÂ object has information about the response itself. To actually get the data, we need to get the body of the response.

Response object

Since the API we're using will returnÂ JSONÂ to us, the returned response will haveÂ .json()Â method. We just need to callÂ .json()Â on the response variable. TheÂ .json()Â method on aÂ ResponseÂ object returns aÂ Promise, so we need to chain on anotherÂ .then().

fetch('https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/todos')
    .then(function (response) {
        return response.json();
    })
    .then(function (data) {
        console.log(data);
    })
    .catch(function (err) {
        console.log("Something went wrong!", err);
    });

Extracted JSON object from Response body

# Headers Object

TheÂ HeadersÂ interface allows you to create your own headers object via theÂ Headers() (opens new window)Â constructor. A headers object is a collection of name-value pairs.

var headers = new Headers();
headers.append('Content-Type', 'text/json');
headers.append('X-Custom-Header', 'SomeValue');

//We can achieve the same can by passing an object literal to the constructor

var headers = new Headers({
    'Content-Type': 'text/json',
    'X-Custom-Header': 'SomeValue'
});

# Supplying options to fetch()

TheÂ fetch()Â method accepts an optional second parameter, anÂ initÂ object that allows you to customise the request.

let reqHeader = new Headers();
reqHeader.append('Content-Type', 'text/json');
let initObject = {
    method: 'GET', headers: reqHeader,
};

fetch('https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/todos', initObject)
    .then(function (response) {
        return response.json();
    })
    .then(function (data) {
        console.log(data);
    })
    .catch(function (err) {
        console.log("Something went wrong!", err);
    });

# Request Object

TheÂ RequestÂ Object represents a resource request. Instead of passing anÂ URLÂ of the resource into theÂ fetch()Â call, you can create a request object using theÂ [Request()](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Request/Request)Â constructor, and pass that as an argument toÂ fetch().Â By passing Request object to theÂ fetch(), you can make customised requests.

let reqHeader = new Headers();
reqHeader.append('Content-Type', 'text/json');

let initObject = {
    method: 'GET', headers: reqHeader,
};

var userRequest = new Request('https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/todos', initObject);

fetch(userRequest)
    .then(function (response) {
        return response.json();
    })
    .then(function (data) {
        console.log(data);
    })
    .catch(function (err) {
        console.log("Something went wrong!", err);
    });

# Conclusion

Definitely,Â XMLHttpRequestÂ wasn't made for the things we are using it today.Â Also, it's APIÂ is a bit more complex without the return on flexibility. TheÂ FetchÂ API makes it easier to make asynchronous requests and handle responses better than using anÂ XMLHttpRequest.Â FetchÂ allows us to create a better API for the simple things, using modern JavaScript features likeÂ promises.

Let's start fetching !!
